title: 106_hr846
content: The "Child Care Worker Incentive Act of 1999" may be cited as the National Child Care Provider Scholarship Program. The "Child Care Worker Incentive Act of 1999" establishes a Child Care Provider Scholarship Program in states to support recruitment, training, credentialing, and retention of child care providers. Eligibility criteria for scholarship applicants are outlined in the state plan. The individual must be a child care worker employed by a licensed provider or have a commitment for employment from one. They must agree to continue working in child care for at least one year after receiving training. The individual is also required to share the costs of the program. The individual, employed by a licensed child care provider, must share the cost of education or training. If applying for a scholarship for an institution in the Pell Grant program, they should also apply for a grant they are eligible for. The employer of the individual must meet certain requirements. The individual's employer must contribute to the cost of education or training and provide additional financial incentives upon completion. The State plan outlines eligible educational programs, including those offered by institutions of higher education participating in student financial assistance programs under title IV. The State plan outlines eligible educational programs under title IV of the Higher Education Act of 1965, leading to credentials in child care or early childhood education. The maximum scholarship grant amount is $1,500 per year, and funds provided will not supplant existing services. The Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990 is amended to authorize $50,000,000 for the Child Care Provider Scholarship Program annually from 2000 to 2004. Allotment adjustments are made to subsections of section 658B. The Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990 is amended to adjust allotments under section 658B and payments under section 658J(a) for states with child care scholarship programs. The Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990 is amended to include reporting requirements for the child care scholarship program, detailing the number of scholarship recipients, grant amounts, completed course credits, and credentials earned. The Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990 is amended to include reporting requirements for the child care scholarship program, detailing the number and percentage of scholarship recipients who fulfilled their 1-year commitment, along with other data as required by the Secretary. The amendments made by this Act will not apply to fiscal years before the enactment date.
